toc_entry.title: The Promised Land
toc_entry.description: Two wetbacks from Mexico inherit the legacy of all immigrants—grueling labor, low pay, and a bleak existence on the edge of the American dream.

toc_entry.title: Easy Money
toc_entry.description: Faster than a speeding Master Charge, funkier than a garage sale, able to leap bad credit ratings at a single bound. Look, up at the sign! It’s a bank! It’s a store! It’s—Super Pawn!

toc_entry.title: Honey, You’Re Still Driving Me Crazy
toc_entry.description: Wise up: that insipid supermarket sugar-water you’ve been putting on your toast isn’t honey. The real stuff—Texas honey—is as full-bodied and distinctive as the nectars that go into it.

toc_entry.title: Why Teachers Can’T Teach
toc_entry.description: Our system of training teachers is a crime that robs taxpayers of millions of dollars, robs potential teachers of competence and self-respect, and robs our kids of a decent education.

toc_entry.title: Football Heroes
toc_entry.description: The best part of Texas high school football is that it’s the biggest thing in town—and still only a game.

toc_entry.title: The Beautiful And the Damned
toc_entry.subtitle: Stepping Out
toc_entry.description: Town & Country magazine came to Texas to record our sophistication, wealth, and savoir faire—and all hell broke loose.

toc_entry.title: Hooping It Up
toc_entry.subtitle: Sports
toc_entry.description: Pickup basketball is not a pastime for the lily-livered or the lackadaisical.

toc_entry.title: Up the Creek
toc_entry.subtitle: Politics
toc_entry.description: Everyone in Austin loves sparkling Barton Creek—especially the developers.

toc_entry.title: Hearts And Minds
toc_entry.subtitle: Church
toc_entry.description: Welcome to Dallas’ First Baptist, the largest Baptist church in the world, with a pastor and a service to match; a more modest path to religious enlightenment leads you to Houston’s Emerson Unitarian.

toc_entry.title: The Truth Hurts
toc_entry.subtitle: Film
toc_entry.description: North Dallas Forty scores but misses the extra point, Dracula bites off more than it can chew, and Peppermint Soda recalls with accuracy the bittersweet days of adolescence.

toc_entry.title: Dust Off Your Blue Suede Shoes
toc_entry.subtitle: Popular Music
toc_entry.description: Then grab your platters and step into the golden era of rock ’n ’ roll.

toc_entry.title: Requiem For A Heavyweight
toc_entry.subtitle: Jazz
toc_entry.description: Charles Mingus was a great jazz musician with a sharp mind, an impeccable sense of rhythm, and a mighty powerful fist.

toc_entry.title: Unfancy Dancer
toc_entry.subtitle: Dance
toc_entry.description: Some have said that life is a dance, and Deborah Hay makes you believe it.

toc_entry.title: Mexican Mystery Tour
toc_entry.subtitle: Books
toc_entry.description: Charles Portis’ new novel belongs to the tradition of great frontier yarns, but this time the young man goes south.

toc_entry.title: Another Roadside Attraction
toc_entry.subtitle: Art
toc_entry.description: Houston National Bank’s “Larger Canvas Two” takes it to the streets.

toc_entry.title: Behind the Lines
toc_entry.description: Waltzing across Texas.

toc_entry.title: The Inside Story
toc_entry.description: Photo jock; teachers’ pest.

toc_entry.title: Touts
toc_entry.description: To bid or not to bid; aye, there’s the rub.

toc_entry.title: Around the State
toc_entry.description: A guide to entertainment and events of more than usual interest.

toc_entry.title: Reporter
toc_entry.description: B-a-a-d government meddling irks Texas goat and sheep raisers; something’s rotten in Rotterdam, and it’s driving up oil prices; and the world’s best gymnasts are coming to Cowtown.

toc_entry.title: State Secrets
toc_entry.description: Not-so-little leaguer finds fountain of youth; schools have to test and tell whether Johnny can’t read; Houston’s new shingle ordinance tries to lock the barn door.
